title: 110_hr2819
content:
The Act titled "Promoting American Agricultural and Medical Exports to Cuba Act of 2007" clarifies payment terms under the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended to define 'payment of cash in advance' as the payment by the purchaser of an agricultural commodity or product before the transfer of title or release of control to the purchaser. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 allows for direct transfers between Cuban and US financial institutions for authorized product sales. A depository institution is defined as a banking entity. Additionally, an Agricultural Export Promotion Program is established for Cuba. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a program to provide information and technical assistance for promoting US agricultural exports to Cuba. This includes maintaining information on the Department of Agriculture's website to aid exporters. Funds from the Agricultural Export Promotion Trust Fund can be used for this purpose. SEC. 5. VISAS FOR ACTIVITIES UNDER TRADE SANCTIONS REFORM AND EXPORT ENHANCEMENT ACT OF 2000. (a) Issuance of Visas for Cuban nationals conducting activities related to purchasing US agricultural goods under the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000. Consular officers may issue nonimmigrant visas if the national is admissible. 
(b) Periodic Reports to be submitted by the Secretary of State to relevant committees every 3 months. The Senate and House committees require reports on visas issued to Cuban nationals for purchasing activities in the US under the Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000. Reports must detail each application and its outcome. SEC. 6. ADHERENCE TO INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS FOR THE MUTUAL PROTECTION OF INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY. Repeal of prohibition on transactions or payments related to US intellectual property under the Department of Commerce Appropriations Act of 1999. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue necessary regulations to implement the repeal and remove any restrictions on transactions. Further regulations will be made to authorize transactions under general license in the Cuban assets control regulations. The text chunk discusses the authorization of transferring trademarks or trade names subject to US law in which a designated national has an interest. The term "designated national" is defined in a specific subsection of the Department of Commerce Appropriations Act of 1999. SEC. 7. TRAVEL TO CUBA. Freedom of Travel for United States Citizens and Legal Residents shall not be regulated or prohibited by the President, including transactions incident to travel to or from Cuba. Regulations restricting such travel or transactions shall be rescinded. Transactions include importation of personal baggage and payment of living expenses in Cuba. The section allows for transactions related to travel to, from, or within Cuba, including banking transactions, but does not permit the importation of goods for personal consumption into the United States from Cuba. The restrictions on importing goods for personal consumption from Cuba do not apply in cases of war, armed hostilities, or imminent danger to public health or safety of US citizens. This section applies to actions taken by the President before and after the enactment of this Act, regardless of other provisions in related acts. Export of medicines and medical devices to Cuba is allowed. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 is amended to remove the requirement for onsite verifications. The President retains the authority to impose export controls on medicines and medical devices to Cuba under certain acts and in response to national emergencies. SEC. 9 of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 amends the airport ticket tax for transportation to and from Cuba, increasing the tax by $1.00 before January 1, 2013. It also establishes the Agricultural Export Promotion Trust Fund under section 9511 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Agricultural Export Promotion Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes from section 4261(c)(4). The fund is available for expenditures to promote American agricultural and medical exports to Cuba. Section 9502(b)(1) of the Code is amended to include an exception for subsection (c)(4) after "sections 4261". Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter A of chapter 98. The amendment to the Agricultural Export Promotion Trust Fund applies to transportation after a 90-day period from the enactment of the Act, excluding amounts paid before that period.
